infotips.asymmetry: Your deviation from perfect 50/50 L/R balance. Under 2.5% is pro level.
infotips.balance: How your power splits between left and right legs. 50/50 is perfect.
infotips.te: Percentage of power going forward. Aim for 70-80% ‚Äî higher isn't always better.
infotips.ps: How even your power is through the pedal stroke. Aim for 20%+. Elite cyclists hit 25%+.
infotips.zones: Time spent in optimal (green), attention (yellow), and problem (red) zones.
infotips.timeInZone: Time spent in each zone. Green is optimal, yellow needs attention, red is a problem.
infotips.score: Overall technique rating combining balance, TE, and PS. Higher is better.
infotips.lastAchievement: Date of your most recent achievement.
infotips.milestone: Name and description of the achievement.
infotips.category: Type of milestone (Volume, Balance, Technique, etc.).
infotips.weeklyActivity: Number of rides per day. Aim for 3-5 rides per week for steady progress.
infotips.compRides: Number of rides compared to last week.
infotips.compHours: Total saddle time. More hours equals more training adaptation.
infotips.compDistance: Total kilometers ridden. Useful for tracking volume alongside hours.
infotips.compClimb: Total elevation gained. Over 2000m per week builds climbing strength.
infotips.compBalance: Power asymmetry vs last week. Lower is better, negative is improvement.
infotips.compOptimal: Time in optimal zone vs last week. Higher is better technique.
infotips.perfScore: Overall technique score from 0 to 100. Higher means better form.
infotips.perfOptimal: Time with all metrics in the green zone. Higher is better.
infotips.perfPower: Average power output in watts. Higher at same HR means better fitness.
infotips.perfEnergy: Total energy in kilojoules. Roughly equals calories burned.
infotips.technique: Pedaling efficiency metrics. TE is power transfer, PS is stroke smoothness.
infotips.balanceFatigue: Left vs right power split. Changes indicate fatigue or compensation.
infotips.fatigueTrend: Overall fatigue trend. Stable is good pacing, dropped is overexertion.
infotips.balanceTrend: Left/right balance trend over time. Consistent values near 50% indicate good symmetry.
infotips.techniqueTrend: Technique metrics trend over time. Look for steady improvement patterns.
infotips.compTe: Torque Effectiveness vs last week. Positive change is improvement.
infotips.compPs: Pedal Smoothness vs last week. Improves slowly, small gains matter.
infotips.fatigue: Technique at ride start vs end. Dropping values indicate fatigue.
infotips.teFatigue: TE change during ride. Drop indicates muscular fatigue.
infotips.psFatigue: PS change during ride. Usually first metric to drop when tired.
infotips.powerAvg: Average power in watts. Track over time to measure fitness gains.
infotips.powerMax: Peak power achieved. Useful for sprints and FTP estimation.
infotips.np: Normalized Power adjusts for surges. Close to average means steady effort.
infotips.cadence: Pedal revolutions per minute. Optimal is 80-95 rpm for most riders.
infotips.hrAvg: Average heart rate. Lower at same power means better fitness.
infotips.hrMax: Peak heart rate reached. Near max often hurts technique.
infotips.speed: Average speed. Less reliable than power due to terrain and wind.
infotips.elevationGain: Total elevation gained. Over 1000m is a serious climbing workout.
infotips.elevationLoss: Total elevation lost. Should match gain on loop rides.
infotips.grade: Maximum gradient. Above 10% is steep, above 15% is very steep.
infotips.energy: Total energy output. Plan nutrition at 250-300 kcal per hour.
infotips.trendCurrent: Value from your most recent ride in this period.
infotips.trendAverage: Average value across all rides in the selected period.
infotips.trendSpread: Difference between best and worst. Lower spread means more consistent form.
infotips.trendLatest: Value from your most recent ride for this metric.
infotips.trendBest: Best value in the period. For asymmetry lower is better, for TE/PS higher is better.
infotips.recentRides: Recent rides with technique metrics. Click any row to see full details.
infotips.tableAsym: Power asymmetry percentage. Lower means more balanced power output.
infotips.tableZones: Time distribution across optimal, attention, and problem zones.

contact.text: For privacy questions, data requests, or account deletion:

privacy.policyChanges: When we make significant changes to this policy, we update the "Last updated" date above. We encourage you to review this page periodically.

accountData.title: Account Data
accountData.intro: When you sign in with Google, we receive and store:
accountData.note: We do not have access to your Google password. Authentication uses OAuth 2.0.

pedalingMetrics.title: Pedaling Metrics
pedalingMetrics.intro: For each ride synced from your Karoo device:

fields.psPurpose: How smooth your pedal stroke is (%)

performanceMetrics.title: Performance Metrics
performanceMetrics.intro: Additional cycling data synced for comprehensive ride analysis:

fields.powerPurpose: Average and maximum power output in watts
fields.hrPurpose: Average and maximum heart rate in BPM

performanceMetrics.note: These metrics provide context for your pedaling efficiency analysis. They are read from your Karoo's connected sensors (power meter, heart rate monitor, GPS).

fields.metricsAvg: Balance L/R, TE L/R, PS L/R

fields.perfAvgPurpose: Averaged performance metrics for that minute

snapshots.note: Snapshots enable the timeline chart in ride details, showing how your technique evolved throughout the ride.

userSettings.title: User Settings (Synced if Signed In)
userSettings.intro: When signed in, your app settings are synced between your Karoo device and web dashboard:

fields.thresholdsPurpose: Balance threshold, TE optimal range, PS minimum
fields.alertPrefsPurpose: Which metrics trigger alerts, vibration/sound/visual options
fields.screenWakePurpose: Whether alerts wake the Karoo screen
fields.bgModePurpose: Collect data even when data field is hidden

userSettings.note: Settings sync allows you to configure thresholds on the web and have them apply on your Karoo automatically. If not signed in, settings remain local only.

drillResults.title: Drill Results (Synced if Signed In)
drillResults.intro: When signed in, your drill training data is synced:

fields.drillTimestampPurpose: When the drill was done and how long it took
fields.timeInTargetPurpose: How long you maintained target metrics

achievements.title: Achievements (Synced if Signed In)
achievements.intro: When signed in, your unlocked achievements are synced:

localOnly.title: Data Stored Only on Your Karoo (Never Synced)
localOnly.intro: The following data is stored locally on your Karoo device and is never sent to our servers:

fields.ratingsPurpose: 1-5 star ratings you assign to rides
fields.notesPurpose: Personal notes you add to rides
fields.onboardingPurpose: Whether you've completed the app tutorial
fields.checkpointPurpose: Temporary ride data saved every minute during rides to protect against app crashes or device restarts

localOnly.note: This data remains on your device. If you uninstall the app, this data is deleted. Crash recovery checkpoints are automatically cleared when a ride ends normally or expire after 24 hours.

dontCollect.intro: While we collect performance metrics for analysis, we specifically avoid location and tracking data:
dontCollect.note: Your rides cannot be traced to specific locations. We only store aggregate performance metrics, not where you rode.

usedNotStored.title: Data Used But Not Stored
usedNotStored.intro: The following data is read in real-time for display purposes but is never saved to device or cloud:

fields.smoothedPurpose: Real-time trend indicators for live display
fields.rawStreamPurpose: Individual data points are processed and discarded; only per-minute averages are stored

permissions.title: Android Permissions
permissions.intro: The KPedal app requests the following permissions on your Karoo:

fields.foregroundPurpose: Run in background to collect data during rides
fields.notificationsPurpose: Show alerts when pedaling technique needs attention
fields.bootPurpose: Start automatically when Karoo powers on

permissions.note: No internet, location, camera, microphone, or storage permissions are requested.

step1.title: Power Meter Pedals
step1.desc: Your pedals transmit balance, TE, and PS via ANT+ Cycling Dynamics protocol to your Karoo.

step2.title: KPedal App on Karoo
step2.desc: The app processes real-time data locally at ~20Hz, calculates averages, and stores ride summaries in local database. Up to 100 rides are kept on device; older rides are auto-deleted.

step3.title: Cloud Sync (Optional)
step3.desc: If signed in, ride summaries and settings are synced to KPedal cloud via HTTPS. Only aggregated data is sent ‚Äî no raw sensor streams. Settings changes on web are automatically applied to your Karoo.

step4.title: Web Dashboard
step4.desc: View your ride history, trends, and analytics at app.kpedal.com. Data is retrieved only for your authenticated account.

dataFlow.offlineDesc: The KPedal app works fully offline. You can use all features without signing in or syncing. Data stays on your device.

infrastructure.title: Infrastructure
infrastructure.workersUse: API processing (serverless). Request logs stored ~7 days.
infrastructure.d1Use: SQLite database for users and rides

security.title: Security Measures
security.jwtDesc: Signed tokens with 15-minute expiry for access, 7-day for refresh
security.rateLimitDesc: Auth: 10 req/min, API: 100 req/min, Sync: 30 req/min. Uses IP address for counting, auto-deleted after 60 seconds.
security.validationDesc: All data validated and sanitized before storage
security.csrfDesc: OAuth state verification prevents cross-site attacks

local.drillResultsPeriod: Until app uninstall (also synced to cloud if signed in)
local.achievementsPeriod: Until app uninstall (also synced to cloud if signed in)
local.settingsPeriod: Until app uninstall (synced to cloud if signed in)

google.title: Google OAuth
google.desc: Used for sign-in only. We request minimal scopes: openid, email, profile.

cloudflare.title: Cloudflare
cloudflare.desc: Our infrastructure provider. Handles API, database, and web hosting.

notUsed: Google Analytics or any analytics service
Facebook Pixel or any advertising tracker
Crash reporting services (no Firebase Crashlytics, Sentry, etc.)

browserStorage.accessPurpose: sessionStorage ‚Äî JWT access token (cleared when tab closes)
browserStorage.refreshPurpose: localStorage ‚Äî JWT refresh token (persists up to 7 days)

thirdParties.browserStorageNote: You can clear this data anytime by signing out or clearing browser storage. No cookies are used.

quickglance.name: Quick Glance
quickglance.desc: Status indicator with balance bar. Shows checkmark when optimal or lists metrics needing attention.

powerbalance.name: Power Balance
powerbalance.desc: Large L/R balance numbers with visual progress bar. Perfect for balance-focused training.

efficiency.name: Efficiency
efficiency.desc: Torque Effectiveness and Pedal Smoothness with L/R splits and averages.

fulloverview.name: Full Overview
fulloverview.desc: All three metrics in one compact view. Complete pedaling picture at a glance.

singlebalance.desc: One large balance number with centered bar. Maximum visibility at a glance.

live.name: Live Stats
live.desc: Real-time balance bar plus time-in-zone breakdown. See your ride stats live.

pedalingscore.desc: Combined score (0-100) from balance, efficiency, and consistency. One number to rule them all.

deltaaverage.desc: Shows how current balance differs from ride average. Spot drift in real-time.

q1.q: Which power meter pedals are compatible?
q1.a:
Full support (Balance + TE + PS): Garmin Rally RS/XC, Favero Assioma Duo/Duo-Shi, SRM X-Power, PowerTap P2, Wahoo SPEEDPLAY Powrlink Zero. These pedals transmit complete ANT+ Cycling Dynamics data including left/right balance, torque effectiveness, and pedal smoothness.

Balance only: Wahoo POWRLINK Zero (single-sided), Stages LR, 4iiii Precision Dual, Rotor 2INpower, Power2Max NG/NGeco. These provide accurate balance data but don't transmit TE/PS metrics.

Not compatible: Single-sided power meters that estimate balance (Stages single, 4iiii single, Assioma Uno) ‚Äî KPedal requires actual dual-sided measurement.

q2.q: How do I install KPedal on my Karoo?
q2.a:
Method 1 ‚Äî Direct download (easiest): On your Karoo, open the browser and go to github.com/yrkan/kpedal/releases. Tap the .apk file to download, then tap the notification to install.

Method 2 ‚Äî USB transfer: Download APK on computer ‚Üí connect Karoo via USB ‚Üí copy to Downloads folder ‚Üí on Karoo, open Files app ‚Üí tap the APK ‚Üí Install.

Method 3 ‚Äî ADB (for developers): Enable Developer Mode on Karoo, connect via USB, run: adb install kpedal-x.x.x.apk

After installation, open KPedal once to grant permissions and enable Background Mode for automatic data collection.

q3.q: Do I need to add KPedal data fields to my ride screen?
q3.a:
No ‚Äî data fields are completely optional. Once you enable Background Mode in KPedal settings, the app automatically collects pedaling metrics for every ride you do. This happens silently in the background regardless of which data fields you display.

Why add data fields then? Only if you want to see your metrics live during the ride. Available fields: Quick Glance (status + balance), Power Balance (L/R with bar), Torque Effectiveness (L/R values), Pedal Smoothness, Full Overview (all metrics), and Balance Trend (smoothed over time).

Your complete ride history with per-minute snapshots is saved whether you use data fields or not.

q4.q: What is considered a "good" power balance?
q4.a:
Optimal range: 48-52% (¬±2% from perfect 50/50). Research shows even professional cyclists typically have 1-3% natural asymmetry ‚Äî perfect symmetry is rare and not necessary for high performance.

Key insight: Consistency matters more than perfection. A rider who's consistently 48/52 is better off than one who swings between 45/55 and 52/48. KPedal tracks your personal baseline so you can spot deviations.

When to be concerned: Asymmetry above 5% sustained over multiple rides may indicate a bike fit issue, muscle imbalance, or developing injury. If you notice sudden changes in your typical pattern, investigate before it becomes a problem.

q5.q: Why is 70-80% Torque Effectiveness optimal and not higher?
q5.a:
The science: Torque Effectiveness measures what percentage of your pedal stroke produces forward motion. TE = (positive torque ‚àí negative torque) √∑ positive torque √ó 100.

Why not aim for 100%? Research from Wattbike and sports science labs shows that above 80% TE, cyclists typically over-pull on the upstroke. This recruits hip flexors inefficiently, increases metabolic cost, and can actually reduce sustainable power output.

The 70-80% sweet spot indicates efficient force application through the power phase (12 o'clock to 6 o'clock) without wasting energy fighting the recovery phase. Elite cyclists naturally fall in this range during sustained efforts.

Lower TE (below 65%) suggests you're "stomping" on the pedals ‚Äî all downstroke, no follow-through. This is common when fatigued or at very high power outputs.

q6.q: What exactly does Pedal Smoothness measure?
q6.a:
Formula: PS = (average power throughout pedal stroke √∑ peak power) √ó 100.

What it means: A higher PS indicates more even power delivery throughout the entire 360¬∞ rotation. Lower PS means you're producing power in sharp spikes (typically at 3 o'clock position).

Typical values:
‚Ä¢ 15-20%: Normal for recreational cyclists
‚Ä¢ 20-25%: Good, efficient pedaling
‚Ä¢ 25%+: Excellent, very smooth power delivery

Context matters: Sprinters naturally have lower PS (explosive power delivery is the goal). Climbers and time trialists benefit from higher PS. During intervals, PS drops as power increases ‚Äî this is normal.

Improving PS: Single-leg drills, high-cadence spinning (100+ RPM), and focusing on "pedaling circles" rather than stomping can increase smoothness over time.

q7.q: How is the Ride Score calculated?
q7.a:
Weighted formula: Balance contributes 40%, Torque Effectiveness 35%, and Pedal Smoothness 25%.

How each metric is scored (0-100):
‚Ä¢ Balance: Based on percentage of ride time within ¬±2.5% of 50/50
‚Ä¢ TE: Based on time spent in 70-80% range
‚Ä¢ PS: Based on time spent above 20%

Score interpretation:
‚Ä¢ 90-100: Elite technique, consistent across the ride
‚Ä¢ 80-89: Excellent, minor room for optimization
‚Ä¢ 70-79: Good baseline, clear areas to improve
‚Ä¢ 60-69: Average, focused technique work recommended
‚Ä¢ Below 60: Significant improvement potential

Pro tip: Compare scores across similar ride types. Your interval workout score will differ from your endurance ride ‚Äî both are valid baselines for their respective efforts.

q8.q: How do the guided Drills work?
q8.a:
Drills are structured exercises with real-time visual feedback. Each drill has multiple phases with specific targets displayed on your Karoo screen.

Example ‚Äî Single Leg Focus drill:
1. Warm-up phase: 30 seconds at natural balance
2. Left focus: 45 seconds targeting 55-60% left leg
3. Recovery: 15 seconds
4. Right focus: 45 seconds targeting 55-60% right leg
5. Cool-down: 30 seconds at natural balance

Scoring: KPedal tracks your time-in-target for each phase. Hit the target range for 80%+ of the phase duration to "pass" that segment. Your final drill score reflects overall accuracy.

Drill categories:
‚Ä¢ Focus: Isolate one metric (balance, TE, or PS)
‚Ä¢ Challenge: Progressive difficulty, multiple metrics
‚Ä¢ Workout: Longer sessions combining technique with effort

q9.q: Can I create my own custom drills?
q9.a:
Yes ‚Äî the Custom Drill builder lets you design exactly what you need.

You can customize:
‚Ä¢ Number of phases (1-10)
‚Ä¢ Duration per phase (10 seconds to 5 minutes)
‚Ä¢ Target metric (Balance, TE, PS, or combination)
‚Ä¢ Target range (e.g., 45-48% balance, 75-85% TE)
‚Ä¢ Phase names and instructions

Example custom drill for left leg weakness:
1. "Warm up" ‚Äî 60s, no target
2. "Left activation" ‚Äî 45s, Balance 54-58% left
3. "Rest" ‚Äî 20s, no target
4. "Left power" ‚Äî 45s, Balance 56-60% left
5. "Equalize" ‚Äî 30s, Balance 48-52%

Sync: Custom drills save to your device and sync to cloud when enabled. Access them on any linked Karoo or view drill history on the web dashboard.

q10.a:
Alerts notify you when metrics drift outside your configured thresholds.

Configurable triggers:
‚Ä¢ Balance: Asymmetry exceeds limit (default: 5% ‚Äî triggers at 45/55 or worse)
‚Ä¢ Torque Effectiveness: Drops below minimum (default: 60%)
‚Ä¢ Pedal Smoothness: Drops below minimum (default: 15%)

Alert methods:
‚Ä¢ Vibration (short buzz pattern)
‚Ä¢ Audio beep (if Karoo sound is enabled)
‚Ä¢ Screen flash (subtle color pulse)

Smart cooldown: After an alert fires, there's a configurable cooldown (15 seconds to 2 minutes) before it can trigger again. This prevents alert spam during sustained difficult efforts.

Per-metric control: Enable or disable alerts for each metric independently. Many riders only want balance alerts, for example, and prefer to check TE/PS post-ride.

q11.q: Does KPedal work without internet connection?
q11.a:
Yes ‚Äî KPedal is fully functional offline. Every core feature works without any internet connection.

Works offline:
‚Ä¢ Real-time data collection during rides
‚Ä¢ All 5 data field types
‚Ä¢ Complete drill library (built-in and custom)
‚Ä¢ Alert system
‚Ä¢ Ride history and statistics
‚Ä¢ Achievement tracking

Requires internet (optional):
‚Ä¢ Initial Google Sign-In (one time)
‚Ä¢ Cloud sync of ride data
‚Ä¢ Web dashboard access

How sync works: Rides are always saved locally first. When you're back online and cloud sync is enabled, data uploads automatically in the background. If you never enable cloud sync, your data stays exclusively on the Karoo ‚Äî your choice.

q12.q: Will KPedal drain my Karoo battery?
q12.a:
Impact: approximately 1-2% additional battery drain per hour during rides.

Why it's minimal:
‚Ä¢ KPedal only actively processes data while you're in a ride
‚Ä¢ Between rides, a lightweight listener waits for ride start ‚Äî nearly zero power draw
‚Ä¢ No GPS usage (Karoo handles that)
‚Ä¢ No continuous background polling
‚Ä¢ Efficient data storage (batched writes, not constant I/O)

Real-world example: On a 4-hour ride, expect roughly 4-8% more battery usage compared to riding without KPedal. Given Karoo 3's 12+ hour battery life, this is negligible for most rides.

Optimization tip: If you're doing an ultra-endurance event and need maximum battery, you can disable KPedal data fields (background collection still works) and turn off alerts.

q13.q: Can I sync data across multiple Karoo devices?
q13.a:
Yes ‚Äî link multiple Karoos to one account for seamless sync.

How it works:
1. Install KPedal on each Karoo
2. Sign in with the same Google account on each device
3. Enable cloud sync on each device

What syncs:
‚Ä¢ All ride data and per-minute snapshots
‚Ä¢ Custom drills you've created
‚Ä¢ Alert settings and thresholds
‚Ä¢ Achievement progress

Use cases:
‚Ä¢ Backup Karoo for race day
‚Ä¢ Different Karoos on different bikes
‚Ä¢ Upgrading from Karoo 2 to Karoo 3
‚Ä¢ Sharing technique data with a coach (they'd need your login)

Conflict resolution: If you ride on two devices simultaneously (unusual but possible), both rides are saved with their respective timestamps. Settings sync uses "last write wins" ‚Äî the most recent change applies.

q14.q: How does the Achievement system work?
q14.a:
Achievements reward consistency and technique milestones.

Achievement categories:
‚Ä¢ Volume: Total rides tracked, hours pedaled, kilometers covered
‚Ä¢ Consistency: Riding streaks (days/weeks in a row with rides)
‚Ä¢ Technique: Ride scores, time in optimal zones, metric improvements
‚Ä¢ Drills: Drills completed, perfect scores, variety of drill types

Example achievements:
‚Ä¢ "First Spin" ‚Äî Complete your first tracked ride
‚Ä¢ "Iron Balance" ‚Äî 10 rides with average asymmetry under 2%
‚Ä¢ "Century Club" ‚Äî 100 rides tracked
‚Ä¢ "Smooth Operator" ‚Äî Maintain 25%+ PS for an entire ride
‚Ä¢ "Drill Sergeant" ‚Äî Complete 50 drills

Progress tracking: View your achievement progress on the web dashboard. Some achievements have bronze/silver/gold tiers (e.g., 10/50/100 rides). Achievements sync to cloud and persist across devices.

q15.q: Can I use KPedal with Garmin, Wahoo, or other bike computers?
q15.a:
No ‚Äî KPedal is exclusively for Hammerhead Karoo.

Technical reason: KPedal is built using Hammerhead's official karoo-ext SDK, which provides deep integration with:
‚Ä¢ ANT+ Cycling Dynamics data streams
‚Ä¢ Native ride state detection (start/pause/stop)
‚Ä¢ System alert infrastructure (vibration, sound)
‚Ä¢ Data field rendering engine
‚Ä¢ Background service permissions

These integrations don't exist on Garmin, Wahoo, or other platforms. Each would require a completely different app built from scratch with their respective (often more limited) SDKs.

Future platforms: There are no current plans to port KPedal to other devices. The project focuses on doing one thing well rather than spreading thin across platforms.

q16.q: Is my data private and secure?
q16.a:
Yes ‚Äî privacy is a core design principle.

Local-first architecture:
‚Ä¢ All data is stored on your Karoo first
‚Ä¢ Cloud sync is opt-in, not default
‚Ä¢ You can use KPedal indefinitely without ever creating an account

If you enable cloud sync:
‚Ä¢ Authentication via Google Sign-In ‚Äî we never see or store your password
‚Ä¢ Data transmitted over HTTPS (TLS 1.3)
‚Ä¢ Stored in Cloudflare's global infrastructure
‚Ä¢ No third-party analytics or tracking
‚Ä¢ No ads, no data selling, no "anonymous" usage statistics

Open source transparency: The entire codebase ‚Äî Android app, web API, and web dashboard ‚Äî is public on GitHub. Audit exactly what data is collected and how it's handled. If you find a security issue, please report it responsibly.

q17.q: Why does my balance change at different power outputs?
q17.a:
This is completely normal and well-documented in cycling science.

The pattern: Most cyclists show 2-4% more asymmetry at low power (Zone 1-2) compared to high power (Zone 4-5). Some riders show the opposite pattern.

Why it happens:
‚Ä¢ Low power: Smaller forces mean small technique variations have outsized percentage impact. Your dominant leg may "take over" when effort is easy.
‚Ä¢ High power: Maximum recruitment of both legs tends to even things out. You're focusing harder and engaging more muscle groups bilaterally.
‚Ä¢ Fatigue: As you tire, your weaker leg fatigues faster, increasing asymmetry. This is valuable data for pacing.

Using this insight: KPedal's per-minute snapshots let you see exactly how your balance changes throughout a ride. Correlate with power zones to understand your personal pattern and target drills accordingly.

q18.q: How often should I do technique drills?
q18.a:
Recommended: 2-3 dedicated sessions per week, plus drill integration into warmups.

Effective approaches:
‚Ä¢ Warmup integration: 5-10 minutes of drills at the start of every ride. Low intensity, high focus. Great for muscle activation.
‚Ä¢ Recovery ride focus: Use easy days for extended technique work (20-30 minutes). Low power means you can concentrate on form.
‚Ä¢ Dedicated sessions: Weekly 30-45 minute technique-focused ride. Structured drill progressions with rest intervals.

Progression strategy:
1. Start with single-metric drills (balance only, TE only)
2. Progress to multi-metric challenges
3. Increase duration and tighten target ranges over time
4. Track drill scores weekly ‚Äî aim for gradual improvement, not perfection

Key insight: Consistency beats intensity. Three 10-minute sessions across a week will improve your technique faster than one 30-minute session. Neural adaptations require regular reinforcement.
